original: Pañca puggalā—🔽Atthekacco puggalo ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.🔽Atthekacco puggalo ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: pañca puggalā  attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti  attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ ārabhati na vippaṭisārī ca hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: Five kinds of persons:🔽There is the case, friends, where a certain person attacks & reviles, but he doesn’t regret it afterwards. He doesn’t discern, as it actually is, the release of awareness where that — by which that person, attacking & reviling, would regret it afterwards — ceases without remainder.🔽There is the case where a certain person attacks & reviles, but he doesn’t regret it afterwards. He discerns, as it actually is, the release of awareness where that — by which that person, attacking & reviling, would regret it afterwards — ceases without remainder.

original: Atthekacco puggalo nārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ na ārabhati vippaṭisārī ca hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: There is the case where a certain person doesn’t attack & revile, but he regrets it afterwards. He doesn’t discern, as it actually is, the release of awareness where that — by which that person, not attacking & reviling, would regret it afterwards — ceases without remainder.

original: Atthekacco puggalo nārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: There is the case where a person does not make an effort to stop unskillful qualities that have arisen, nor is he remorseful about them afterwards. He does not understand the liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, where those unskillful qualities that have arisen cease without remainder.

original: Atthekacco puggalo nārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: attha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: There is the case where a person does not make an effort to stop unskillful qualities that have arisen, nor is he remorseful about them afterwards. He does understand the liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, where those unskillful qualities that have arisen cease without remainder.

original: Datvā avajānāti, saṁvāsena avajānāti, ādheyyamukho hoti, lolo hoti, mando momūho hoti.
analyzed: da tvā avajānāti sa vāsena avajānāti ādheyya mukhaḥ hoti lolaḥ hoti mandaḥ momūhaḥ hoti
translated: One disparages after giving. One disparages through living together. One is difficult to support. One is fickle. One is slow-witted, dull, obtuse.
Five types of persons are like warriors.🔽Five types of alms-food eaters.
Five types of sit-onlys.🔽Five types of rag-robe wearers.

analyzed: pañca tecīvarikā  pañca āraññikā  pañca rukkhamūlikā
translated: Five types of triple-robe wearers.🔽Five types of wilderness dwellers.🔽Five types of tree-root dwellers.

analyzed: pañca abbhokāsikā  pañca nesajjikā  pañca yathāsanthatikā
translated: Five types of open-air dwellers.🔽Five types of any-bed dwellers.
